job_title: Medical Laboratory Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros:
Good pay and benefits
Positive work environment/diverse
Friendly boss and coworkers
Fun events/free food occasionally/bonuses/pto/work around your schedule
Conducive to asking questions and for help
Desk job (your choice of sitting or standing at a computer). Not physically back breaking or manual labor.
cons:
Requires a lot of training (6 weeks at least) to learn the job but once you learn it you know it well. Feels like a lot of information during your training but like everyone says, you will learn it solidly before being on your own. If there is something about the job you don't know how to do, there is always someone to call or ask for help. 

Jobs where patient care is your number one priority can be a bit intimidating or stressful at times since it is important to follow procedures to ensure the hospital's patients get the best care possible. Occasionally you do see surgical samples with removed patient organs or small amputations for study (we do not touch these samples or open the containers they are in if you are squeamish - we simply check that the containers are labeled correctly, etc. and send them to other areas of the hospital for them to do the testing). I get squeamish easily however I manage these samples fine since we do not actually touch them or anything like that if that is a worry.

One con is you do work one major holiday or two small holidays a year. However, most jobs require that. You can easily try to trade these holidays as well.

review_title: Great place for patients, not always great place for employees
pros: Nationwide Children's Hospital does a really wonderful job caring for sick children. Feeling like you are part of that mission is powerful.
cons: Nationwide Children's Hospital wants to make sure every child is being cared for, however, in order to do so employees need to feel valued and cared for as well. This isn't always the case and employees feel overworked, underpaid and undervalued all while taking care of the sickest children. Do better NCH. If you want to make sure these sick children continue to have the best care, you need to make sure you have the staff to take care of them, the staff to hire those people, the staff to keep employees engaged, the staff to feed the children, employees and families, the staff to clean up after them and to protect them.

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Columbus, OH
pros: NCH is a great training environment for post docs. Many opportunities for professional development are available both through the trainee organization and through Research Institute sponsored programs.
cons:
While NCH has a rather large research institute in the context of a children's hospital, it still lacks some of the benefits of a large university. The larger seminar series tend to have a heavy clinical focus and cover broad sets of topics so it can be hard to find seminars that fit your interest directly on campus. 

NCH does have the benefit of being closely association with OSU and many more incredibly interesting seminar series can be found there.

The pay isn't great for a PhD level scientist but that is a general issue with postdoc positions rather than a specific NCH policy.

pros: Overall very positive atmosphere and attitude, lots of perks and special benefits available to employees, welcoming environment.  The institution continues to be on the way up.
cons:
Working with sick children can be depressing, especially at the holidays.

Surrounding community is a bit sketchy, albeit improving.

You'll have to park and walk a few blocks and cross busy streets, or take a shuttle bus, unless you are a physician/senior management.

You must use vacation time for hoildays.

No separate vacation time and sick time, encouraging sick employees to show up for work in order to save vacation days.

Treatment of employees varies dramatically supervisor to supervisor.  

On this last point: My supervisor was incredibly brilliant but absolutely tyrannical, and working for this person was a horrific nightmare I would never wish upon anyone.  I left because I no longer cared to be screamed at, demeaned, threatened, etc.  The work environment was always tense and oftentimes miserable, and my coworkers suffered terribly during my time there.  I dreaded coming to work and spent my weekends dreading Monday.  I worked long hours, weekends, and holidays, making my salary woefully inadequate...not that any level of pay could compensate for this kind of treatment.

To their credit, hospital HR was very understanding and offered to help me find employment elsewhere in the hospital, but my experience there was so negative I just wanted to get out and NEVER go back.

That said, others in positions similar to mine but working under different supervisors had much better, very positive experiences.  Proceed with caution.

My rating for my personal experience at Nationwide Children's is 1/5 but in general I'd give the place a 4.

pros: Dental and eye insurance are great.
cons: No maternity leave.  Have to use pto for holidays and the first three sick days.  The saying "everything matters" is not true, the company does not pay attention to work/life balance. The company only pays attention to the diplomas and not experience when giving promotions and hiring.  Getting an adequate cost of living raise is difficult.  The health insurance is lacking considering it is a hospital.  Parking is horrible and preference is given not to employees who have been here longer, flex shift or to emergency personnel but to nursing and residents.   Staff are afraid to speak up, they end up with a target on their back.  In the last 8yrs, the hospital has changed the logo multiple times and all of the items that cost with the change instead of giving their staff adequate raises or salary increases.

pros: You get to work with kids
cons:
Everything else - you're constantly treated like crap by management, the nurses, and the parents
- worst health insurance of any healthcare facility I've worked at
- managers don't have a clue how to manage - my manager actually said in a staff meeting, "I don't have time to put on scrubs to come in and find out what you do."  She automatically sides with the nurses on everything, even when there's clear evidence that the nurses are wrong.
- RNs get hired directly out of nursing school for ICU areas and are inadequately trained to work there - some of them don't even bother to chart correctly for patients
- if you work in a clinical area, you will work with some really wonderful, intelligent nurses, but most of them are just rude and stupid.  There are RNs here I would never allow near anyone I care about
- there is an unbelievably high level of turnover, but no one bothers to consider that it could be the managers so it's never addressed or solved; Walmart may actually have a lower level of turnover than the NICU.

Outside recruitment gets more fair offers, but still just a lateral offer from your current pay or even a pay cut. Losing highly talented people left and right because of it.

review_title: My overall employment experience was very good
job_title: Unable to Disclose and Maintain Anonymity in Columbus, OH
pros: Nursing management is excellent - advocates for nurses on their units.  There are great opportunities for learning and professional growth. Nurses are passionate about providing the absolute best care of the children.  NCH has the BEST Chief Nursing Officer and Nursing Vice Presidents around.  They are in touch with staff, they are assessable and involved.
cons: Non patient care areas are not staffed sufficiently to provide the level of support that people want to give.  Hospital expansion occurred without the infrastructure in place to handle the 2,000+ additional staff that was hired.

pros: Independent work environment, dedicated clinical staff, modern facilities, community involvement, patients are the priority
cons: Very few job growth opportunities - they post jobs when they already know who they are going to hire.  High turnover, demanding workload, below average salary and benefits, parking, cubicle village in a deteriorating offsite building, loud work area, low morale

pros: Great hospital with cutting edge research and resources. Nice equipment, new buildings, and many new planned expansions.
cons:
Parking is a nightmare.  Expect to drive to a distant parking lot and be shuttled to the hospital.....taking 25-35 minutes each way.  Management divides staff into two groups: physicians and managers, everyone else.  There are special reserved areas for this "important group", everyone else is left to distant lots in unsafe areas.

Benefits are subpar when compared to hospitals in the area. PTO (168 hours including vacation, holiday, and sick time for full time status) is very low starting out and for the first 10 years. Holiday pay comes out from your PTO bank (6 per year).

pros:
- Senior leadership has great reputation in the academic community
- Huge emphasis on good outcomes for patients with a variety of medical conditions
- Cutting edge technologies are used on a daily basis
cons:
- Middle/lower management is completely ineffective and does not care about staff level employees (lab techs, support staff)
- Non-innovative work environment with no flexibility.  Employee clock-in/out monitored to the minute
- Lab staff are treated like children and monitored closely
- Inconsistent enforcement of rules. Merit raises are completely subjective and reduced with little to no explanation or evidence
- Money is spent freely to accommodate comfort of upper management.  Staff often do not have the tools they need for their jobs
- No advancement opportunities,  No pay increases besides average annual merit raise ~2%.  Employee has to provide his/her own evidence to support merit raise.

job_title: Behavioral Intervention Aide in Columbus, OH
pros: Great pay, flexible hours. Mileage reimbursement and payment for drive time. Moving up through the company is not difficult; about 6 months-1 year is the timeline for promotions.
cons:
I was easily swayed because of the organization and because of the reputation of the hospital. I worked at the Autism Center, which is not at the main hospital.  I quickly found out that I was very much on my own, with no one to help train me or help advocate for me.  It's a very independent job.  You are subjected to weeks of training, only to find out the trainings you received have not prepared you at all.
The work itself is very, very difficult, which was not relayed to me at any point in the interviewing/training process.

job_title: Quality Outreach Coordinator in Columbus, OH
pros: Attracts top talent, plenty of resources available, prestige, looks good on a resume
cons: Everyone is treated as replaceable. You're a small part in a huge company and you aren't made to feel like you matter. The company talks a big game about caring about their employees and work-life balance, but when something actually comes up, they are rigid and completely uncaring. There is a policy that you can't say anything that might negatively effect their "brand" so if you don't like it, you can't actually express it. Their handle on integrity is questionable and they invest in and protect management, even when that management is terrible. Employee turnover is astronomical. It's all about numbers and money, even though they constantly talk about how patient care is most important, it's not.

review_title: OK if you need experience, but not a place to stay long term.
pros: Staff and management very friendly on a personal level, good place to gain knowledge and experience in your field. They do have genuine concern for their patient's well-being.
cons: Poor benefits; few holidays (must use PTO time), high health insurance costs, and poor raises that are below the cost of living.  You are constantly told that the hospital doesn't have money for raises yet spends enormous amounts of money remodeling hospital or for new flashy signs and logos.

review_title: Very good community, great place to work at
pros: I worked in the IT department for the summer as an intern. The employees were very laid back, but were interested in their work. Lots of opportunities for career advancement. My department was very helpful in allowing me to obtain more opportunities of work (actual work, not leftovers). I was really satisfied with the amount of workload
cons: The cafeteria location wasn't great. The only place where one could find a place to relax under the sun was the Subway location. The food was okay, but leaves much desired.

review_title: Good place to work, if money is not the driving force behind your employment.
pros: The mission is what stands out.  What we do is important not only for the families, but for the communities that we serve.  I feel good about what I do, and I am proud of who I work for.  Job security is second to none.  There is so much growth that budget is what holds the employee numbers down.
cons: Compensation is rather low compared to industry standards (i.e. the dept that I work in, and not necessarily Healthcare as a whole).  I know people who do less, and get paid more, in other industries.

review_title: The supervisor/manager is apparently always right.
pros: Seemed to be opportunities for advancement.  The benefits were decent.  The centralized locale was nice.  Building and cafeteria were decent.
cons: Don't even bother disputing a manager decision with HR.  They will act as though they are fair, but once you complain, even if eligible for rehire, you are BLACKLISTED.  For 9 months of my unemployment, I applied weekly for positions that I was qualified and/or over-qualified for and was sent an automated denial each time.  This was after working for the company for years.

pros: Amazing orientation process that stays with you for however long you are employed @NCH (over 5 years personally). All employees treat each other with the utmost respect regardless of position, department, or level of educational background. Really great place for both employees and for the children being treated there medically
cons: I'm not sure I can think of any cons at the moment.. NCH is a great stepping stone for just about any healthcare-related career path, and potentially also the place where you decide to just stay forever

review_title: Registered Nurse, Amulatory RN at an outpatient clinic
pros: There are a lot of opportunities if you are motivated. For advancement, learning, trainings...etc.
cons: They have a bank for all paid time off that you accumulate and mandatory holidays that take hours out of that bank. So for example, if you work outpatient at a clinic, you will lose 16 PTO hours if your clinic is closed for Thanksgiving and the day after. Noone is happy about this but upper management claims it's necessary to pay for our "benefits."

pros: Working for a Children's Hospital gives meaning to your daily tasks. Knowing that the job you do will have an impact on a sick child, even indirectly, means that you make sure that you focus on quality every time.
cons: Lower pay than comparable jobs at other local employers, by a significant margin. This is a very risk adverse environment, so change is hard to push through even when its clearly needed. In Information Services where I work, much of the staff is converted from a clinical setting, and have no outside IS experience.  While that is helpful knowing the users environment and needs, its does not push the technology in the direction we need to go in.

review_title: I couldn't be more favorable of Nationwide Children's Hospital.
pros: They care about their employees, patients, and visitors. They honestly do live up to their cliche slogan of ' Everything Matters!' Vacation and benefits couldn't be matched if there was a union. Simply put, GREAT EMPLOYER.
cons: Management is typically promoted from within based on tenure rather than job performance. The shift times are a little skewed for anybody who works in a supportive department. (Cashiers, Security, Engineering, Custodial, Clerks, etc.)

job_title: Managed Care in Lewis Center, OH
pros: Supportive team of nurses, if it were not for all involve, the insanity would have dragged us down further.
cons:
Blatant lies to staff
Favoritism ot employees 
Use of PTO for holidays, bereavement, FMLA and emergency family care.
Management falls under the umbrella of personality, not professionalism 
Billing and wirte-offs are astonomical.  If it were not for the inappropiate billing practices grants and fundraising could be cut minimally.   For those who had commerical insurance, families were harrassed constantly and not provided with outsourced options when medical needs were at high dollar value.   It was shameful and disgusting.   HIPAA violations breached on daily basis and reports pushed aside.    HR ignored request for meetings verbally and written.

review_title: Spend more on people, less on buildings
pros: Important mission, for the most part the employees are great, some growing pains in recent years due to rapid expansion
cons: I can't speak for the hospital side, but in research we are losing good people due to stagnant wages and lack of opportunity for individual growth. We just aren't as competitive as we were before all of our money went into building new facilities.

pros: Working with the families and their children is difficult emotionally, but the benefits are more than worth it. Some of the physicians are friendly and support the staff no matter what level of the department they are working in (housekeeping up to fellow physicians).
cons:
Very high turn over rate, pay is not competitive with other hospitals in the area, no holiday pay (you must use your PTO), no maternity leave (yep no maternity leave in a children's hospital), raises are of maximum 3% and that is only if you perform at what management considers above average so you can also be given less, management is unprofessional and cliquey, lateral violence is rampant among a large majority of the nurses as well as the non clinical staff, I witnessed and was the recipient of racism, sexual harassment, unethical practices, harassment, and homophobia.

As a non RN in this organization you are basically treated as a disposable employee. The hospital goes above and beyond to protect it's nurses no matter what offenses they may have done, including jeopardizing patient health. Because management must hold a nursing degree, they often side with the nursing staff and consider complaints to be "making waves". Many of my legitimate concerns were not addressed and in contrast were pinned back to me. 

Any hard work you do will be overlooked and ideas are often accredited to management who did not originally conceive them. Make one mistake? Expect management to solely focus on your short coming instead of utilizing the moment to make these opportunities to uplift you. 

HR is also not going to be of any help. As mentioned in many other reviews, HR will always side with management and will not address your concerns. If you happen to have the audacity to bring things up the ladder to HR, you will be met with anger and backlash once you return to your department as there is no transparency in the process.

review_title: Be prepared to learn and habitually work long days to meet productivity
pros: Decent compensation including mileage reimbursement, some flexibility to create your own schedule (at least in behavioral health) including the ability to occasionally work in between sessions using a hospital-assigned laptop, commitment to clinically and culturally-competent work, financial incentives for high-performing staff (though this is extremely difficult to achieve even for the seasoned clinicians), high volume of referrals means a never-ending crop of new clients to be seen, interdepartmental communication is excellent, clinician safety is a priority for the company therefore therapists are never expected to remain in high-risk situations, cell phones are provided for use
cons: Very high productivity standards, little organization in how cases are assigned therefore clinicians end up traveling quite a bit to get from A to B, 24-hour charting is next to impossible with the existing productivity standard when culminated with the repetitive and complex nature of a completing a single case note, high to very high turnover means lots of new faces you barely get to know since there are no offices for non-managing clinicians (just a big room with a bunch of people working on their hospital-assigned laptops and talking on cell phones), lack of structure for some programs while other programs have quite a bit of structure and offer extensive training in order to adhere to the directives of the program's model, clinicians are suggested to maintain boundaries regarding scheduling as to not get burnt out however productivity requirements dictate clinicians meet with clients primarily on the client's schedule (leading to clinicians working a few hours in the AM - especially if there is a meeting, followed by a long gap if clients cancel, and then trying to make this up during the remaining PM hours), a few supervisors and staff appear to lack much of a personality and come across as cold and rigid - even to the point of ignoring you when you attempt to greet them in the hallway

pros: The care of the children is the #1 forefront; regardless of ability to pay. The nurses and staff on the patient units genuinely care about the patients!
cons: Bad management; seems as though that you have a bad manager and nothing can be done about him/her even when you go to HR.  Most of the time, employees do not leave a job because of the job but because it is due to a poor manager.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Columbus, OH
pros: You are paid well and the people that work there are great.
cons: Children's is a hectic work environment - but if you are a pharmacy technician you are used to it. The training is not done very well - but if you motivate yourself to learn on your own you will be okay.

pros: Best and only place in Central Ohio to practice pediatric subspecialties
cons: Managers are generally weak and top leaders don't replace them when they are clearly incompetent.

pros: Great hospital, recognized for innovation, growth, strategic vision, mission driven...We are here for the children!! My experience has been from difficult to great, highly team dependent. I've hung in there enough to make observations and contribute to change. There's always more to do! Overall awesome place to work and the longest employer I've ever worked for.
cons: Research and hospital are two very different cultures. Research employees need more integration and support from hospital to ensure hospital values integrated with Research Management. Most research is grant driven and that drives a different sub-culture that can work contrary to hospital values. There is not a bridge between Research and Clinical. Lots of talent lost bc lack of understanding on how to maximize potential of innovative research talent with healthcare opportunities. Lower pay drives tenured employees out for growth opportunities and compensation. NCH will not pay for advanced degrees unless earned before becoming an employee. Be prepare to look for another job if advanced degree earned, unless you are a nurse. NCH looses great talent bc salary is not competitive. It's easier to leave, advance education and gain more experience then return for increased earnings. This leads to a void for organization. On the business side of Research, grants management is the backbone and the culture leads to high turnover, resistant collaboration and poorly trained staff that creates a negative ripple effect throughout projects.

pros: Many children who are treated at Nationwide Children's Hospital are being treated for debilitating illnesses or injuries.  I felt honored that through my work I was able to help the children and families in a small way.
cons: The growth is so incredibly fast that employees cannot keep up with the changes due to lack of communication.

job_title: Float Licensed Practical Nurse in Reynoldsburg, OH
pros: The pros are the patients. I love knowing how much that I am impacting families every single day. The nurse educator is awesome, she has been incredible since the first day on the job. Always available to answer questions and to find the solutions to problems. My manager is also very supportive.
cons: The biggest con is communication. There are so many people in charge that the left hand is working against the right hand. Very hard to get answers to things about time off and other technical problems and such.

pros: Great Mission, great people. Lots of training opportunities internally and with external partners.
cons: Few opportunities for advancement. Parking is pretty bad but "in the works". Formal mentoring is available for physicians, but no one else. Job candidates from outside NCH are valued for their experiance over internal candidates, even those that NCH has put thousands of dollars into training for.

pros: The staff are really really friendly and overall they push a great friendly environment for the visitors.   Overall a nice place to work
cons: Health care benefits are adequate and the salaries are low in comparison to others.   Also benefit sign up process is not very user friendly.   A lot of long term employees that do not like change.

review_title: It's OK.  Very friendly, and lots of small perks, but low paying.
pros: Good management in my department, lots of support for projects, large education/ travel budget.  I have lots of freedom to do my job the way I want to, but most of that is because of my direct superior.
cons: Mediocre health benefits, annual increases restricted to 3%, low paying.

review_title: wish i could've used my 8 years somewhere else
job_title: Cardiology Technician/Administrative Assistant in Pickerington, OH
pros: you can use your badge to get food in the cafeteria.
cons:
using your badge comes off your check, regardless if you go to school or degree, if you dont know someone your not going to be able to move around. Some departments are so unbearable to work in. and human resources doesnt have your back. 
at the end of the day if you dont know someone your not getting in or moving around.
And I hate to say this but black people really arent moving around. if you get in your stuck in that position forever.

pros: This is a very exciting place to work. The culture is amazing and you're motivated to work hard for a "purpose". There is no doubt that patients and families are top priority and it makes you feel good about coming to work everyday. You are proud to tell people where you work.
cons: The benefits are lacking because of the amazing culture you get from being part of a pediatric hospital. The pay is lower in comparison, it takes a long time to build up vacation time, insurance/etc. are expensive.

review_title: Supervise a team of Patient Access Representatives for two autism clinics
job_title: Lead Patient Access Representative in Columbus, OH
pros: I love this company, and I truly believe that they strive to live up to their moral integrity. This is the best place I’ve ever worked for.
cons: Being a nonprofit, it sometimes makes the office politics more difficult. Sometimes management seems to be spread too thin.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Columbus, OH
pros: Very growing, great management, attentive to staff improvement. Inclusive and open to community. Open to new ideas and easy to contribute to the greater good.
cons: Growing almost too fast, culture is changing, still good but different than when it was smaller. I believe there are processes in place to help navigate this though.

review_title: Unless you REALLY love kids, avoid.
job_title: Emergency Department RN in Columbus, OH
pros: Pediatric care is better than adult care.
cons: Low pay, high turnover, poor management, bullying

pros: The children are what keeps you going and they truly are doing great things at the hospital.
cons: Everything is very slow to progress. Not much room to go. Either you've been here for many years or you stay in the entry position with maybe a promotion but very little raise.

review_title: Good job stability but other areas need improved
pros: I've never heard of anyone getting laid off at Nationwide Children's Hospital. They offer good health insurance and are constantly instituting quality improvement initiatives to benefit patients.
cons: It doesn't seem like anything is done when managers consistently receive low employee satisfaction surveys and have high turnovers in the department. One team principles are talked about but not implemented. Lower compensation compared to other hospitals. You can't apply for anything internally unless you notify your current manager.

pros: It is and extremely diverse environment. The core facilities are very useful in expanding your research horizons. The place is constantly growing
cons: The expansion seems to come at an expense of the existing facilities. Why the existing facilities aren't improved before building new ones is beyond me. There is a huge disconnect between the hospital and the research areas.

review_title: Unexperienced, lying, deceiving manager how treated the employees as replacable and not like a person.
pros: Focused on the quality of care for children.  Great benefits.
cons: HR will not support the employees for any reason, if the manager wants to fire you they will.  My manager was unexperienced, uneducated (no degree), hid vital information from senior management.

review_title: It's wonderful to work in a place that really has purpose and meaning, with everyone smiling.
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: The kids! They also build a huge new facility that is absolutely beautiful. Their new labs are also state-of-the-art. They have an excellent shuttle service and they support their employees - even student researchers.
cons: Sometimes there is not a ton of coordination between departments, making it seem a bit bureaucratic. It is very large, and there are also multiple campuses, which can make parking a hassle.

pros: The organizational executive leadership has a wonderful attitude towards quality outcomes and innovation.
cons: Department level managers are unopened to doing things other than their way and tend to have a chip on their shoulder.

pros: It truly is a fair place to work. People are, in general, happier than other hospitals. Good work is being done. Projects are interesting. There are interesting people there, and an immense amount of intelligence in the Research Institute. It was a great place to be while I was there.
cons: Parking is pretty much terrible, though it's gotten better recently. The construction is confusing.

review_title: good place to work but could/should be more competitive
pros: The hospital and research institute are very dynamic and expanding dramatically. The mission is worth working for. Very friendly and respectful environment.
cons:
The work done at the research institute is not recognized nationally and internationally, which make future opportunities more difficult to create.
Salaries could be much better.

review_title: Great experience if you're not concerned with advancement or compensation
pros: The work environment in the Research Institute is great and relaxed.  Plenty of good people to work with and work for.  Includes a Gym facility and great Employee Wellness incentives.
cons: Annual reviews and salary are bare minimum and below cost of living, which means you're losing money every year you work there.  Benefits are so-so, but could be less expensive.

job_title: Program Manager in Le Havre, Normandy
pros: The company respects their employees. Offers gifts, celebrations, parties, and little touches out the wazoo. Keeps environments clean and pleasant to work in. Senior leadership approachable and down to earth. Colleague respect is a must. Truly believes in the goal- to provide care to all children- and that everything matters to our families.
cons: May need to review salaries to remain competitive- and increase benefits for tenured employees- but in today's market, I can't really complain.

pros:
The hospital has very high standards of care and very competent and dedicated staff.
It is a large hospital and has a lot of resources for employees to benefit from.
Management is very transparent to staff and also the public.
Most employees there like working there.
Overall a great place to work.
cons: As with any hospital nursing job, it's difficult to get a position with ideal hours.  Any days off need to be scheduled 6 weeks in advance which can be difficult.

review_title: Toxic environment- petty, catty women get in the way of care
pros: Working with kids. Helping families. Light physical labor
cons: Gossip, cliques, awful managment, lack of anonymity and covering up violations

pros: i had an amazing experience. the people are amazing and all the staff are extremely friendly. everyone has a purpose and they are a part of the team
cons: the only con i would say is the security at the front gate. the hospital is situated in a bad area in columbus. the security is not bad just more is needed

pros: Nice facilities. Staff are good with children.
cons: They work everyone extremely lean. Everyone has many jobs. Bullying is known and tolerated. They lose many good people due to this. Pay is ok. Flexible.

pros: Amazing environment, top of the line equipment and research teams. Amazing and innovative physicians, nurses, and employees. Children are a privilege to care for.
cons: Feeling confused about choosing an insurance plan, HR not offering much support with this and I am new to this stuff. Young single mother, wanting to make the best decision. Doing a lot of reading and googling.

review_title: The research institute provides good, stable, and engaging jobs.
pros: Great mission to go above and beyond the standard of care for children. Top notch research and ability to collaborate.
cons: Watch out for politics and culture when you choose a lab to work in!  Some labs thrive with participation and feedback while other labs require you to earn your keep before your opinion really makes a difference. Mostly good labs, but just watch out for the drama!

job_title: RN Care Coordinator in Columbus, OH
pros:
NCH is a great place to work. You make a difference in a child's life every day. It's a beautiful new hospital and seeing the children and families there every day is awesome. 
Good benefits
Good pay 
Employee Focused
cons: Parking can be a hassle. Some lots are pretty far and the shuttle system is inconvenient. As with everywhere health insurance has gotten more expensive the last few years.

review_title: Best Company I've Ever Worked For!
pros: Their mission is to provide the best outcomes for all of our patients. I've never worked for a company that cares so much. No matter your job, or where you work, everyone's there to give the children the best in patient care.
cons: Being that it's such a large company and has such a reach in the community, it's easy to feel disconnected from the main campus if you don't work there every day.

review_title: This is my second home and I love being a part of an organisation that puts children first.
pros: The patients, the staff, the environment, the culture, the diversity, the friendliness, the realness, the atmosphere, the ability to grow and flourish in the hospital and branch out to other departments and areas.
cons: The repetitiveness, not a vast selection of food, ideas are not always taken into consideration, and all they have are diet drinks.

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Columbus, OH

review_title: Until management makes changes avoid working here
pros:
I can only think of 3 pros to working at Nationwide Children’s Hospital:

1. good co-workers

2. get to help patients (this would be true anywhere)

3. for me it’s relatively close to my family
cons:
There are a lot of reasons not to work at Nationwide Children’s Hospital.  If you have any other choices I’d recommend you take them over NCH.  Until management makes some changes this is not a good place to work.  Three of the biggest issues I have are:

1. Management overworks everyone.  Most doctors, nurses, and staff at NCH are pretty unhappy.  Since I started at NCH about 5 years ago the workload has steadily increased.  The amount of time you have to see each patent has been reduced.  The number of clinics you have to do has increased.  The number of publications you need to have to get promoted has increased.

2. NCH has a very restrictive non-compete clause.  The non-compete clause is non-negotiable and extends for 100 miles.  This prevents you from being able to work anywhere in Columbus or in nearby cities such as Dayton and Cincinnati.  NCH added the non-compete clause because too many doctors were leaving to go to work in Cincinnati or Dayton.  Instead of trying to make the work environment better they just decided to add a non-compete clause to prevent anyone from leaving.  Before working at NCH you need to ask yourself why they need a non-compete clause that extends for 100 miles.  They have very few patients from Cincinnati so a doctor working there wouldn’t be in competition with NCH.

3. Too much focus on the bottom line and profits instead of patient care.  NCH is bad about replacing people who leave.  To save money they try not to hire new staff and instead just force everyone else to do more.  This hurts patient care.

job_title: Quality Outreach Coordinator (Partners for Kids) in Columbus, OH
pros: Nationwide Children's Main Hospital has a great reputation, I've heard wonderful things about working there. Benefits were fine and rate of pay was good.
cons:
I worked for Partners for Kids and had the worst employment experience. I am typically very positive about my work and those that lead me. However, I have never experienced something quite like PFK. If you are interested in a care coordination/quality outreach position beware that the majority of your time will be spent making, what are essentially, sales calls. They push you to contact people's emergency contact numbers just to get patients to enroll in the program. You are also expected to contact non-enrolled members' providers and ask for patient phone numbers to call which leads to other providers to feel uncomfortable and angry because typically this information is not shared. While this is legal, I did not find it ethical. Again, no information regarding these calls were disclosed during interviews.  

In addition, they have overhired causing a majority of  new employees to have empty caseloads and new employees are expected to make these "enrollement calls" until they have something to do. However, there is clear irritation by leads and management when new employees don't have caseloads and the new employees are blamed for management's overhiring practice.

The interview process was quick and easy and I should have trusted my gut that the urgency was not a good sign. My biggest regret is not waiting for a position with the actual main hospital. Do not take this as a negative review of Nationwide Children's Hospital, which is a wonderful organization. However, I would steer clear of any jobs at Nationwide Children's Partners for Kids Program. What a disappointment.
